text: As a member of @SenateBanking, I promise to continue to build on the legacy of the Freedman's Bank by working with underserved communities to establish trust in banking, build financial literacy & take further steps to close the wealth gap. (2/2)

On March 3, 1865, the Freedman‚Äôs Bank was established to help newly freed African American men & women as they transitioned to freedom. Despite initial successes & intervention from Frederick Douglass, the bank closed after less than a decade ‚Äî devastating thousands. (1/2)

Learning is a beautiful and organic process. It is not rigid. It can‚Äôt be measured with a one-size-fits-all approach.

Test-centric bureaucracy robs our children of the exploration necessary for real learning. We need to end this racist, classist, discriminatory practice.

We can‚Äôt teach our children to be scared of getting an answer wrong. We need to teach them how to lead, and learn from their mistakes.

At the middle school I founded, we took this approach and immediately saw positive growth as a result. https://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20160330/eastchester/bronx-principal-lauded-for-test-growth-now-speaks-out-against-them/

Those who succeed in our world don‚Äôt do so because they can prepare for a one-time test. They succeed because they can think creatively, confidently, and critically.

Developing those skills must begin in early childhood education, and continue through HS.
https://www.publicschoolreview.com/blog/are-public-school-students-prepared-for-the-real-world

Institutionally, standardized testing has been used to vilify educators and teachers unions, close schools, and tear down, rather than be used as part of a solution.

Individually, standardized testing makes our students less confident and less curious. I‚Äôve seen it firsthand.

We need to reimagine our schools as places where the brilliance and multiple intelligences of every single student are nurtured.

Our dependence on testing signals to our under-resourced students that they are at fault for not fitting into a narrow definition of intelligence.

Alfie Kohn has spoken on standardized testing. He rightly calls out that standardized tests aren‚Äôt actually meant to assess, improve, or help our students.

They have been used to separate them ‚Äî typically along racial or class lines. https://www.alfiekohn.org/article/standardized-testing/

So if the system isn‚Äôt closing the achievement gap, and it isn‚Äôt benefiting our students, what is it doing?

David Quinn of USC found that the discourse was creating more biases about Black and brown students ‚Äî rather than alleviating them. https://sdp.cepr.harvard.edu/blog/achievement-gap-discourse-has-downside

The 2002 passage of so-called ‚ÄúNo Child Left Behind‚Äù prioritized high-stakes standardized testing as a means for assessing students and educators, and providing statistics that could help us close the achievement gap.

But in the 19 years since, the achievement gap hasn't budged.

It is a fact, not an opinion, that our standardized testing system discriminates against kids who learn differently. It also discriminates against poor kids. Black and brown kids as well.

I need you all to understand the root causes of why. Take this journey with me.

Together, these two bills tonight are about changing systems: our system of politics and our system of criminal justice. We can only do better for everyone when the systems are built to allow us to do that. Today was an important step in that direction (end)

This was a key part of what I heard when I did a series of listening sessions last year with community groups and law enforcement. There was a lot of common ground and common purpose. This bill is a step towards achieving that.
This bill achieves that by banning practices like chokeholds and taking other steps to change the culture of our public safety so it works for everyone.
Best practices, accountability, bringing our police and our communities closer together make for better, safer communities. That's our goal.

This bill is actually the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act. It's named after Mr. Floyd because he serves as a reminder of a broken system. Broken for communities of color and broken for our men and women in uniform who serve and protect.
That means we have a system that can truly tackle the big challenges of our time. One of those challenges is racial justice. That's where the second bill, the #JusticeInPolicingAct comes in.

When our system doesn't work for you, it doesn't work. And when our system doesn't work, it doesn't work for you. We've seen that so many times over the past few years. This bill makes the changes we need to make the system work, and work for you.

This bill does a lot of things, but it comes down to a few key categories: 1) it protects every American's right to vote and makes our voting systems safer, 2) it finally fights back against dark money, and 3) it strengthens our ethics laws to weed out bad actors.

Let's start with #HR1, the #ForThePeople Act. This is a bill that I fought for even before I came to Congress. It's a bill that strikes at the core of what so many people I talk to every day are frustrated by: a system that works for big money and influence, not every day people.
Tonight we're voting on two important bills in the House. I want to take a quick minute to tell you why in this moment it was critical we bring them up for a vote (thread)

The JUSTICE Act incentivizes trainings to reduce use of force, ends the use of choke holds, and promotes transparency by enhancing the use of body cameras. It‚Äôs time America works to support and improve our law enforcement agencies - not defund them.
I've cosponsored a common-sense alternative to this bill called the JUSTICE Act which implements many of the same provisions while still protecting our law enforcement personnel.
We are a nation based on the rule of law - defunding our police is not a viable option, and stripping them of their ability to operate is a dangerous path to go down.
We saw an unprecedented spike in murders in 2020, particularly in places where there were efforts to undermine our law enforcement officers or defund their agencies.

This bill eliminates qualified immunity which protects law enforcement personnel from frivolous lawsuits unless they violate a person‚Äôs rights or break the law. Our police need to know they can take proper & necessary actions w/o fear of being sued for simply doing their jobs.

THREAD: We all agree that our justice system needs common sense reforms.  Unfortunately the Justice in Policing Act we voted on in the House today would make it nearly impossible for law enforcement officers to do their jobs and keep our communities safe.

More than half (53%) of workers who would benefit are adults between the ages of 25 and 54, their most productive years. About 3 in 5 of these workers work full-time (35+ hours per week). http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EvkxrPYXMAE2WS7.jpg

The vast majority (91%) of workers who‚Äôd benefit would be adults over the age of 20, not teenagers. And an overwhelming share (81%) of them would be high school graduates, not high school students as critics often claim. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Evkxk9AXEAYJ8Ld.jpg

Importantly, approximately one in five U.S. workers would get a raise. 

Further, people who make more than the minimum wage, even more than $15 per hour, will also get a raise. 

That's because the #RaiseTheWage Act raises the wage floor. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EvkxEY_WgAA5zSH.jpg

Some key points: 

Recent projections by @USCBO and others estimate that raising the wage to $15 an hour by 2025 would benefit more than 25 million workers, the vast majority of whom are adults‚Äîmost working full-time.

Her advocacy didn‚Äôt end in the legislature; Thelma founded the Boys and Girls Clubs of Alaska, the Filipino Heritage Council of Alaska, and the Asian Alaskan Cultural Center.

This remarkable woman not only made history in our state through her election not the legislature, she also made American history by becoming the first Filipino-American legislator in the entire country.

We cannot serve the people properly if we do not treat them with respect. Or to say it another way, no one should be disrespected. Not Anna, not anyone. 14/14

Public service demands the best of us. We should be held to high standards. We should have the capacity for respect for each and every person we meet, no matter how brief. Our job is to literally serve the people. 13/14
Respect should be the starting point, not the finish line, and harm should never be done. 12/14

How do we serve people if we don‚Äôt treat them with dignity and respect? This goes beyond just public officials too. Our concern is not just about how people treat strangers. Must also be about our colleagues/staff, our family/friends, our competitors, our acquaintances. 11/14

I heard in my friend‚Äôs voice what happens when we encounter people who disrespect us, sometimes crossing lines without knowing or caring. As elected officials, we hold positions of perceived power and have solemn responsibility to examine our actions through that structure. 10/14

I can never fully understand what Anna and others experienced, but from their truth I hope it forces people in power - and everyone else - to ask these difficult questions and look at their own actions with increased scrutiny. 9/14

Years later now as a public official myself, I carry so many of those 30 second moments with me when I meet people. I ask myself: am I giving this person my respect? Am I treating this person as I‚Äôd want to be treated? 8/14

Anna and I worked at White House several years ago. Young staffers surrounded by powerful people. It was intimidating. I don‚Äôt know Anna‚Äôs experience, but in my career, I saw a huge range of how people respected and disrespected others, especially women and people of color. 7/14

I thought all night about that line she said. When we meet people, especially strangers, how do we want to spend that time together? But it also fundamentally gets at the question of respect. Do we respect the people we meet? Do our actions reflect respect? 6/14

She paused in her description and asked if that is how he wanted to spend the 30 seconds with her, a complete stranger, what does that say about him? She paused again and reframed the sentence, ‚Äúthat is how he chose to spend the 30 seconds meeting me.‚Äù 5/14

Something she said to me stood out. She remarked how the encounter with Governor Cuomo was brief but was seared into her memory with a deep vividness. I could tell it still made her uncomfortable to think about it as that strong, confident tone began to soften. 4/14

It was hearing from other women of their experiences of sexual harassment, assault, and abuse that got her to stand up and speak out. Anna did not compare her experience to those of others, but instead said she wanted to let others know that she is with them in solidarity. 3/14

Anna sounded strong. She always has been for the years I‚Äôve known her and her voice was confident. We talked about why she decided to share her story. She was honest about how she struggled with the decision. Ultimately, she felt compelled to say something. 2/14

My dear friend Anna Ruch stepped out the other day to share with us a story that is difficult to tell, especially when the whole country is watching. I called her last night. Not knowing exactly how she might be feeling, I asked How are you doing?
